summary: This 1940 West Africa Court of Appeal decision addressed a post-judgment application concerning the repayment of excess amounts paid under a reversed lower court judgment. The original Divisional Court had awarded the plaintiff-respondent £1,644 10s. and costs of £73 18s. 6d. On appeal, the Court reduced the award to £250 and set aside the costs order. The defendants-appellants sought repayment of the difference (£1,394 10s.) plus interest and costs, which the lower court refused due to lack of authorization in the formal certificate. The appellate court held it possessed inherent power to make consequential orders, citing Evans v. Main Colliery Co. Ltd., and ordered repayment of the overpaid sum including costs, with interest at 4% per annum from the date of the order, rejecting interest from the original payment date but affirming the defendants' entitlement to restitution.
verdict: The Court granted the application, ordering the plaintiff-respondent to repay the overpaid amount with interest from the date of the order.
citations: Evans v. Main Colliery Co., Ltd., (1915) W.N. 10
rationaleHighlights: The Court has inherent power to make consequential orders after judgment.
Failure to include repayment in the initial certificate does not bar a later order.
The logic of the lower court's refusal supports the appellate court's authority to act.
Defendants are entitled to restitution of overpaid sums following reduction of judgment.
Interest awarded from the date of the appellate order, not from original payment date.
No costs awarded on the application due to procedural timing issues.
Cited authority: Evans v. Main Colliery Co. Ltd. supports supplemental orders.
The formal certificate does not limit the Court’s jurisdiction to correct imbalances.
